paragraphs.text: Here's what happens when oil prices crash - and it's not pretty for producers.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: The longest and biggest oil boom in history is over
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In a boom - and the latest one lasted almost 10 years- everything shines for producer nations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the economy grows
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: consumption explodes
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: businesses make fat profits regardless of their productivity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: poverty declines even if social protection programmes are ineffective
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: politicians are popular and get re-elected even if they are incompetent and corrupt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: people tend to be happier
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: oil prices tend to be cyclical
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when the downturn comes, the party ends
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: During the oil price decline of the 1980s, most oil-dependent countries suffered the consequences of the resulting collapse in investment and consumption
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: A few, such as Oman and Malaysia, were able to compensate for the price collapse by increasing production
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: many oil exporters suffered, also due to the production cuts agreed by Opec
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some recovered better than others
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: in general between 1982 and 2002 they fared much more poorly than the rest of the developing world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Those that fared worst were typically the ones that got into debt during the boom
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Poverty and unemployment rose sharply
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: such underperformance led to the widespread idea that having oil is a curse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which has generated extensive literature
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The reality is more complex
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as shown by economic overperformance during the past decade's boom
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: taking out those two "bust" decades, oil countries have outperformed their peers over the past 70 years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So the real "curse" is in fact an oil price collapse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The current price collapse - for the first time since 2009 prices are below the symbolic $50 a barrel- is largely a result of the boom in shale oil production in the US, adding more than 3m barrels over the past few years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: High prices bring investment and supply
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: this boom was no different
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Oil prices are notoriously difficult to predict
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we do not know if the current bust will last
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: despite evidence that points to at least two more years of lower prices
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Moreover
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: prices are still above historical standards
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For the majority of the more than 120 years of history of the oil industry the price has been below $50 in today's money
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: But geopolitics or renewed consumption could alter the oversupply scenario and surprise us once again
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: oil busts tend to lead to booms down the road precisely because investment in oil exploration dries up
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Net importers, like most European countries, will benefit from the oil price decline
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the US, citizens will pay significantly less for gasoline than they have over the past five years
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: leading them to spend more on other goods
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A vast transfer of wealth from exporters to importers is occurring
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the fall is short term
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: some pain will be suffered by all net oil exporters
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it will only be disastrous for the countries that failed to learn the lessons of the previous boom and bust cycle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This time around many countries have saved a larger part of their windfall and invested more in productive assets, although generally significantly less than the value of the resource being depleted
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many abandoned their conservative fiscal policies during the financial crisis of 2008-09
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which made sense
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they never got back to the prudence of the first few years of the boom
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Middle Eastern producers were prompted to increase spending by the unrest produced by the Arab Spring
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Still
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: with few exceptions, most exporters are in better shape to weather the storm
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The wealthy countries of the Gulf, and some of the Caspian countries, can easily manage a temporary fall in prices
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they have accumulated large external funds
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: although
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: some face more worrisome long- term fiscal prospects
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even Russia is in a better position to manage the oil fall than the Soviet Union was
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it would still suffer from the necessary cuts in imports and spending
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the sanctions will hurt more
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Iran is in worse shape
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because it had a less prudent economic policy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: sanctions had already produced a crisis even before the fall in the oil price
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nigeria, despite an improved macro policy in comparison with the previous boom, is going to be significantly affected due to its excessive dependence on oil
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: leading to an increase in poverty and political instability
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Angola is also vulnerable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Latin American oil exporters with generally prudent macro policies, like Colombia and Mexico, will also be affected by the necessary fiscal adjustment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they should be able to manage it with limited trauma
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: no country is in worse shape entering into the price collapse than my home country, Venezuela
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As the proverbial grasshopper of the fable, Venezuela did not only spend throughout the summer, mostly in consumption
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it also went into a debt binge to afford even more consumption
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the country was running deficits of 15%-20% of GDP during the peak boom years
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Now comes the winter
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it faces economic collapse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Inflation could top 100% in 2015
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: shortages are widespread
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there is a high probability that many Venezuelans who came out of poverty during the boom will fall back into it, with serious consequences for political stability
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Oil abundance is not necessarily a curse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Most producers are better prepared this time around
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: for the few that learned nothing from the past, the reality will be as harsh as the grasshoppers' winter
paragraphs.label: assumption
